aliases.name: Ninety-Nine Gods
aliases.meaning: Translation referring to 99 years before animation

description.summary: Japanese yokai of household objects that gain sentience and animation after 100 years of existence. Rooted in Shinto animism and Buddhist concepts, these spirits embody respect for objects and anti-wastefulness philosophy.
description.full: Tsukumogami are a class of Japanese yokai where household items and tools gain sentience after reaching 100 years of age. The concept stems from Shinto animism (belief that all objects possess spiritual essence) combined with Buddhist teachings. These animated objects can range from benign pranksters to vengeful spirits, particularly if they were mistreated or carelessly discarded. Common examples include Karakasa (umbrella yokai), Bakezori (sandal spirits), and Kameosa (sake jar spirits). The tradition encourages respect for possessions, gratitude, and environmental consciousness, values still celebrated in modern Japanese culture through practices like Hari Kuyo (needle memorial service).

etymology.origin: From Japanese 'tsukumo' (九十九, ninety-nine) and 'gami/kami' (神, god/spirit)
etymology.meaning: The term refers to objects that have existed for 99 years, on the verge of their 100th year transformation
etymology.cultural_significance: Reflects Japanese concepts of mottainai (regret over waste) and animistic worldview

physical.appearance: Varies by object type - typically the original object with added anthropomorphic features (faces, limbs)

features.description: Often develop eyes, mouths, sometimes noses on the object surface
May sprout arms, legs, or tentacle-like appendages
Retains recognizable characteristics of original object

physical.morphology: Animated household objects with varying degrees of anthropomorphization

abilities.description: Ability to move independently after 100 years
Can communicate, often to complain or play pranks
Some possess magical abilities related to their original function

behavior.temperament: Benign or vengeful depending on how they were treated
patterns: Vengeful actions if mistreated or discarded carelessly

common_varieties.name: Karakasa

common_varieties.name: Bakezori
common_varieties.description: Animated sandals that run around at night making noise

common_varieties.name: Kameosa
common_varieties.description: Old sake jar spirit that licks up spilled sake

common_varieties.name: Biwa-bokuboku
common_varieties.description: Musical instrument yokai that plays itself

common_varieties.name: Chochinobake
common_varieties.description: Lantern with one eye and long tongue

range.description: Traditional belief throughout Japan, part of Japanese cultural heritage

origins.cultural_roots: Shinto animism combined with Buddhist concepts of impermanence and attachment
origins.earliest_accounts: References in Heian period literature and emakimono (picture scrolls)
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader yokai traditions in Japanese folklore

cultural_practices.hari_kuyo: Needle memorial service where old/broken needles are thanked and laid to rest
cultural_practices.significance: Demonstrates ongoing cultural practice of respecting objects

traditions: Buddhist teachings on impermanence and attachment
folklore.beliefs: Objects that served faithfully deserve respect and gratitude
